bestBHT.bht: For this very purpose, I have sent Tychicus to carry my letter, so that he may know your state and comfort your hearts. Through Tychicus, I hope to inform him of your reception of the false teachers, your love, concord, and afflictions, so that he may provide support and encouragement to you. It is my desire that through this letter, you may come to know the things that concern us and that it may bring comfort to your troubled hearts.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: that he may know your state
Marvin Vincent: I have sent. Epistolary aorist. Tychicus carried the letter.
He might know your estate [γνω τα περι υμων] . The correct reading is gnwte ta peri hJmwn ye might know the things about us, or our estate.
Philip Schaff: Whom I sent, etc. See Ephesians 6:22, which is verbally identical.
The best Greek manuscripts nearly all read as in Ephesians.
The weight of authority overbears the probability of an alteration to conform with Ephesians 6:22.
Archibald T. Robertson: I have sent (επεμψα). Epistolary aorist active indicative of πεμπω as in Ephesians 6:22.
That ye may know (ινα γνωτε). Second aorist (ingressive) active subjunctive of γινωσκω, 'that ye may come to know.' This the correct text, not γνω (third singular).
May comfort (παρακαλεση). First aorist active subjunctive. Proper rendering here and not 'may exhort.'
John Gill: That is, to relate to them his affairs both temporal and spiritual; and also, that he might know your estate.
What reception the false teachers had among them; and what love, concord, and harmony were among themselves; or what were their afflictions and distresses from their enemies.
Who might be greatly cast down upon hearing of the sufferings of the apostle, and also with those they themselves endured both from within and from without, from sin, Satan, and the world.

The correct reading is that he may know the things about us, or our estate. Through Tychicus, I hope to inform him of your reception of the false teachers, your love, concord, and afflictions, so that he may provide support and encouragement to you. It is my desire that through this letter, you may come to know the things that concern us and that it may bring comfort to your troubled hearts.
